DHS’s March 30 guidance allows removal to a third country without notice if the United States has received credible diplomatic assurances that the country will not subject the individual to torture. The plaintiffs argue that such policy violates their statutory and constitutional rights.

No settlement has been reached, and no monitor has been appointed. The case remains active, with the court continuing to oversee discovery, enforce its preliminary injunction, and await the resolution of the appellate dispute.
results.46186:
On February 28 2025, a class‑action complaint was filed in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts by Svitlana Doe, Maksym Doe, Maria Doe, Alejandro Doe, Armando Doe, Ana Doe, Carlos Doe, Omar Doe, Sandra McAnany, Kyle Varner, Wilhen Pierre Victor, and the Haitian Bridge Alliance (hereafter “Plaintiffs”) against Secretary Kristi Noem, Acting Director Caleb Vitello, Acting Commissioner Pete R. Flores, Senior Official Kika Scott, and President Donald J. Trump (“Defendants”).  The complaint alleges that the Trump administration, on January 20 2025, issued Executive Orders 14165, 14159, and 14161 that directed the Secretary of Homeland Security to terminate all categorical parole programs—including the “CHNV” program for nationals of Cuba, Haiti, Nicaragua, and Venezuela—and to exercise the parole authority only on a case‑by‑case basis.  Acting Secretary Benjamín Huffman subsequently issued a memorandum ordering DHS to pause and terminate the CHNV program, and Acting Deputy Director Andrew Davidson issued a February 14 memorandum suspending the adjudication of all immigration‑benefit requests for parolees under U4U, CHNV, and FRP.  A Federal Register notice published on March 25 2025 formally terminated the CHNV program and rescinded existing parole grants.  

The plaintiffs contend that these actions violate 8 U.S.C. § 1182(d)(5) (the statutory parole authority) and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by being arbitrary, capricious, and lacking procedural safeguards.  They seek declaratory relief that the programs are lawful, injunctive relief that the termination and benefit suspension be halted, and a vacatur of the agency actions.  

The court entered an order on April 14 2025 granting class certification to all individuals who had received a grant of parole under the terminated programs and who had pending re‑parole or other benefit applications.  The same order issued a preliminary injunction and stayed the termination of the CHNV program and the suspension of benefit adjudications for the class.  Defendants appealed, and on May 8 2025 the Supreme Court granted a stay pending appeal of the district court’s stay, thereby maintaining the injunction until the appellate decision is rendered.  The case remains pending in the First Circuit and the Supreme Court, with the plaintiffs continuing to seek the full restoration of their parole status and the resumption of immigration‑benefit processing.
results.46180:
On February 25, 2025 the American Federation of Teachers (AFT), the American Sociological Association (ASA), the AFT‑Maryland affiliate (AFT‑MD), and the Eugene School District 4J filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland (Baltimore Division). The plaintiffs allege that, on February 14 2025, the U.S. Department of Education (DOE), through Acting Assistant Secretary for Civil Rights Craig Trainor, issued a “Dear Colleague Letter” that re‑interprets Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Supreme Court’s 2023 decision in *Students for Fair Admissions v. Harvard* (SFFA). The letter, plaintiffs say, imposes new, over‑broad prohibitions on teaching about race, on student affinity groups, and on diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) programming, and threatens enforcement action—including the loss of federal funding—within 14 days.

The complaint seeks declaratory and injunctive relief. Plaintiffs claim the letter and an accompanying “Certification Requirement” (issued April 3 2025) violate the First Amendment (by chilling protected speech and association), the Fifth Amendment (by being unconstitutionally vague and over‑broad), and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by being a final agency action issued without notice‑and‑comment and without a proper administrative record. The remedies requested are a declaratory judgment that the letter and certification are unlawful, a preliminary injunction to bar enforcement of those documents, and a permanent injunction to prevent future enforcement or reliance on them.

The defendants are the DOE, Secretary of Education Linda McMahon, and Acting Assistant Secretary for Civil Rights Craig Trainor. The case is not a class action; each plaintiff is a distinct entity (a national union, a professional association, a state affiliate, and a school district) suing the federal agency and its officials in their official capacities.

Procedurally, the plaintiffs amended the complaint on March 5 to add the school district as a plaintiff. They filed motions for preliminary injunction on March 28 and April 9, 2025. The court granted the injunction on the letter (staying it under § 705 of the APA) but denied injunctive relief on the certification requirement because the complaint had not yet challenged it. On April 24, 2025 the court granted summary judgment on counts 1, 2, 3, 5, and 6 of the amended complaint, and denied count 4. The memorandum opinion, issued August 14 2025, held that the letter and certification are unlawful under the APA, the First Amendment, and the Fifth Amendment, and vacated both documents. The court also entered a stay of the letter and issued an order requiring the DOE to cease enforcement actions tied to the letter and certification until the merits are decided.

No settlement has been reached. No monitoring parties were named. The case centers on the Department’s attempt to expand the scope of Title VI enforcement to include a wide range of DEI‑related educational practices, and the plaintiffs’ assertion that the agency overstepped its statutory authority, violated constitutional rights, and failed to follow proper administrative procedures.
results.46119:
On February 13, 2025 the United States District Court for the District of Maryland received a complaint filed by a group of current and former employees and contractors of the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), who use the pseudonym “J. Doe 1‑26.”  The plaintiffs allege that Elon Musk, acting “in his official capacity,” together with the United States DOGE Service (the Department of Government Efficiency) and the Department of Government Efficiency, directed the DOGE to infiltrate USAID, seize control of its computer systems, remove the agency’s website and headquarters, and put employees on administrative leave or terminate contracts, thereby violating the U.S. Constitution’s Appointments Clause and the separation‑of‑powers doctrine.  The plaintiffs seek declaratory relief and injunctive relief to prevent further unlawful actions and to restore access to email, systems, and employment status.

The complaint was served by private counsel (the plaintiffs’ attorneys were not named).  The case was brought under 28 U.S.C. §§ 1331 and 2201; venue was proper under 28 U.S.C. § 1391(b) and (e) because at least one plaintiff resides in the district.

On February 18, 2025 the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction.  Judge Theodore D. Chuang granted the injunction on March 18, 2025, ordering the defendants to (1) restore access to USAID email and other systems for all affected employees and contractors; (2) refrain from disclosing any of the plaintiffs’ personal data; (3) refrain from taking any further actions that would shut down or dismantle USAID, including terminating contracts, employees, or office facilities; and (4) submit a written agreement indicating that USAID will be able to occupy its Washington, D.C., headquarters.  The district court found that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits, would suffer irreparable harm, the balance of equities favored the plaintiffs, and the injunction was in the public interest.

On March 19, 2025 the defendants filed a motion for clarification of the injunction, arguing that the order also applied to Jeremy Lewin, the USAID Deputy Administrator, who was not a defendant.  Judge Chuang denied the motion on March 20, 2025.  The defendants then appealed the injunction.  On March 28, 2025 the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted a stay of the district‑court injunction pending the appeal (Judge Quattlebaum, joined by Judge Niemeyer, with Judge Gregory concurring in the result).  

The plaintiffs have pursued the use of pseudonyms throughout the proceedings and have sought to proceed under Local Rule 102.2(a) waivers.  No settlement has been reached, and the case remains pending, with the appellate court continuing to consider the merits of the constitutional claims and the propriety of the preliminary injunction.
results.46099:
On January 20, 2025, President Donald Trump signed Executive Order 14169, “Reevaluating and Realigning United States Foreign Aid,” directing the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to implement a 90‑day pause on all U.S. foreign development assistance. Four days later, Secretary of State Marco Rubio issued a memorandum to U.S. diplomatic posts that suspended new foreign‑aid obligations and ordered the issuance of stop‑work orders for existing grants and contracts. U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) followed suit, instructing its grantees—among them AIDS Vaccine Advocacy Coalition (AVAC) and Journalism Development Network (JDN)—to halt work and to minimise costs incurred under the affected awards.

On February 10, 2025, AVAC and JDN filed a complaint in the District Court for the District of Columbia seeking declaratory and injunctive relief. Their claims were based on the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and on constitutional grounds, alleging that the executive order and the Secretary’s memorandum violated the Take‑Care Clause, the separation of powers, and the APA’s prohibition of arbitrary and capricious agency action. The plaintiffs requested that the court enjoin the defendants from enforcing the freeze and stop‑work orders, and that the defendants be compelled to resume disbursement of appropriated funds.

On February 12, 2025, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO) and for a preliminary injunction. Judge Amir H. Ali granted the TRO on February 13, 2025, enjoining the Department of State, USAID, OMB, President Trump, Secretary Rubio, and Director Russell Vought from enforcing or giving effect to the executive order, the Secretary’s memorandum, and any related directives. The TRO required the defendants to take all steps necessary to comply with the order and to provide written notice to all foreign‑aid recipients.

The defendants filed status reports and motions, but on February 20, 2025, Judge Ali reaffirmed the TRO and ordered the defendants to resume funding for all awards existing as of January 19, 2025, and to pay all amounts due to the plaintiffs’ grants and contracts. On February 25, 2025, the court issued an order enforcing the TRO, directing the defendants to pay all invoices and letter‑of‑credit drawdowns for work completed before the TRO by 11:59 p.m. on February 26. The defendants’ attempts to stay the order were denied.

On March 4, 2025, the court held a hearing on the plaintiffs’ request for a preliminary injunction. The court granted the injunction in part, holding that the defendants’ blanket freeze was arbitrary and capricious under the APA, that plaintiffs had suffered irreparable injury, and that the public interest favored the injunction. The injunction required the defendants to stop enforcing the freeze, to resume disbursement of appropriated funds, and to cease issuing stop‑work orders.

The case remains pending. The defendants have filed appeals on the preliminary injunction, but the court has not yet ruled on those appeals. No settlement has been reached, and no monitor has been appointed. The factual basis of the case is the sudden halt of foreign‑aid funding that left AVAC, JDN, and other recipient organizations unable to pay staff, to continue programs, and to sustain international health and journalism initiatives. The plaintiffs’ litigation seeks to reverse the executive order’s effect and to restore the flow of appropriated funds.
results.46093:
The case, docket 2:25‑cv‑00255, was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington on February 10 2025.  The plaintiffs are a group of refugees and their families—Pacito, Esther, Josephine, Sara, Alyas, Marcos, Ahmed, Rachel, and Ali—who are seeking admission to the United States, along with the nonprofit resettlement agencies HIAS, Church World Service, and Lutheran Community Services Northwest.  The defendants are federal officials sued in their official capacities: President Donald J. Trump, Secretary of State Marco Rubio, Secretary of Homeland Security Kristi Noem, and Acting Secretary of Health and Human Services Dorothy A. Fink (later substituted by Robert F. Kennedy Jr.).

The plaintiffs allege that President Trump’s Executive Order 14163, “Realigning the United States Refugee Admissions Program,” and the agencies’ implementation of that order—including an immediate suspension of all refugee admissions, a halt to refugee‑processing decisions, and a stop‑to‑work order that cut federal funding to the resettlement agencies—ultra‑vires the Refugee Act of 1980 and violate the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Constitution’s due‑process clause.  The claims rest on the statutory framework that Congress created a permanent, systematic refugee‑admissions program and requires the President to act with appropriate consultation.  The plaintiffs seek declaratory relief affirming the illegality of the order and its implementation, and injunctive relief—both preliminary and permanent—to halt the enforcement of the order and restore the agencies’ funding and operations.

Judge Jamal N. Whitehead issued a preliminary injunction on February 25 2025 that enjoined the defendants from implementing Executive Order 14163, from suspending refugee processing and admission, and from withholding funding to the resettlement agencies.  The injunction was partially stayed by the Ninth Circuit in Pacito v. Trump (No. 25‑1313) on March 25 2025, with the court holding that the injunction applies only to refugees who had been conditionally approved for admission before January 20 2025 and had arranged travel.  The district court, however, retained jurisdiction over the injunction’s enforcement and, on March 24 2025, issued a second preliminary injunction that broadened the scope of relief to cover the defendants’ termination of cooperative agreements that funded refugee processing and reception‑placement services.

The defendants moved to stay the injunction pending appeal, but Judge Whitehead denied the motion, finding that the defendants were unlikely to prevail on the merits and that the injunction was necessary to protect the refugees’ reliance interests.  The Court also issued a compliance‑framework order to clarify the defendants’ obligations, appointing a neutral to review individual reliance‑interest claims.  Subsequent orders revisited the framework in light of a further Ninth Circuit clarification that narrowed the class of protected refugees, and the court ultimately issued an implementation framework and appointed a magistrate judge to oversee the compliance process.

Throughout the litigation, the plaintiffs continue to pursue both declaratory and injunctive relief, while the defendants seek to restore the suspension of refugee admissions and the termination of funding for resettlement agencies.  The case remains active, with the court maintaining the injunctions and overseeing the defendants’ compliance under the framework established by the district court and clarified by the Ninth Circuit.
results.46065:
On February 7, 2025, the Attorney General of Washington, acting for the states of Washington, Oregon, Minnesota, and later Colorado, filed a complaint and declaratory‑injunctive action against President Donald J. Trump (in his official capacity) and a broad coalition of federal agencies: the Department of Justice (DOJ), Health and Human Services (HHS), Agriculture, Commerce, Defense, Education, Energy, Veterans Affairs, NASA, National Science Foundation, the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, and others. The plaintiffs also named three physicians—faculty at the University of Washington—who provide gender‑affirming care to minors. The complaint alleges that President Trump’s Executive Order 14,187 (the “Medical Services EO”) and the related Executive Order 14,168 (the “Gender‑Ideology EO”) unlawfully condition federal research and education funds on the denial of gender‑affirming services to children and criminalize such care under 18 U.S.C. § 116, thereby violating the Constitution’s separation of powers, the Fifth Amendment’s equal‑protection clause, the Tenth Amendment’s protection of state police power, and the Fifth Amendment’s due‑process clause for vagueness. Plaintiffs seek a declaratory judgment that the orders are unconstitutional and injunctive relief preventing the agencies from enforcing or implementing the orders.

On February 14, 2025, the district court granted a temporary restraining order, enjoining all defendants except the President from enforcing Section 4 of the Medical Services EO, which requires federally funded institutions to “immediately … end” the use of puberty blockers, hormone therapy, and other gender‑affirming treatments for patients under 19. A subsequent motion for a preliminary injunction was filed on February 19, 2025, and on February 28, 2025 the court granted a preliminary injunction that extended the TRO to also enjoin the agencies from enforcing Sections 3(e) and (g) of the Gender‑Ideology EO, which prohibit federal funding for programs that “promote gender ideology” and require agencies to “end the federal funding of gender ideology.” The court found the orders violated the Constitution’s separation of powers and equal‑protection guarantees, and that the plaintiffs had standing and likely success on the merits. The preliminary injunction made the TRO permanent pending further proceedings.

On March 6, 2025, plaintiffs filed a motion for contempt, arguing that the National Institutes of Health had terminated a grant to Seattle Children’s Hospital and that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention had issued a notice that conflicted with the TRO and preliminary injunction. The court denied the contempt motion and denied attorneys’ fees, but granted plaintiffs’ alternative request for expedited discovery to investigate the alleged violations. In April 2025, defendants filed a motion to stay the case pending appeal, and on April 23, 2025 the court granted a limited stay, allowing plaintiffs to enforce the injunction while the appeal proceeds.

No settlement has been reached. The court’s TRO and preliminary injunction remain in effect, and the case continues through discovery and potential appellate review.
results.46028:
PFLAG, Inc.; the American Association of Physicians for Human Rights, Inc. (“GLMA”); and six transgender minors—Gabe Goe, Bella Boe, Cameron Coe, Robert Roe, Lawrence Loe, and Dylan Doe—and their parents brought a federal action in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland on February 4, 2025.  The plaintiffs allege that President Donald J. Trump, through two executive orders (14‑168, “Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government,” and 14‑187, “Protecting Children from Chemical and Surgical Mutilation”) unlawfully directed the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and its components—Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA), National Institutes of Health (NIH), and National Science Foundation (NSF)—to withhold or condition federal research and education grants on the basis that a recipient provides gender‑affirming medical care to a patient under nineteen.  The plaintiffs claim that the orders violate the separation of powers, the U.S. Constitution’s Equal Protection Clause (as applied through the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause), and statutory nondiscrimination provisions of the Affordable Care Act (Section 1557) and the Public Health Service Act (Section 1908).  They seek declaratory relief and injunctive relief, including a temporary restraining order (TRO) and a preliminary injunction.

On February 5, 2025 the plaintiffs filed an emergency motion for a TRO.  The court granted the TRO on February 13, 2025, enjoining the agency defendants from enforcing or implementing the orders’ funding‑condition provisions.  A memorandum opinion justified the TRO on the grounds that the orders were ultra‑vires and that the injunction’s scope was appropriate.

The plaintiffs then moved for a preliminary injunction on February 18, 2025.  The court granted the injunction on March 4, 2025, issuing a nationwide order prohibiting all defendants—except the President—from conditioning, withholding, or terminating federal funding for gender‑affirming care of minors under the challenged executive orders.  The order required the defendants to file status reports and to comply with the injunction’s terms.

On March 7, 2025 the plaintiffs filed an emergency motion to enforce the preliminary injunction.  The court denied that motion on March 28, 2025, holding that the defendants’ subsequent notices to grant recipients violated the injunction.  The defendants appealed the preliminary‑injunction ruling on April 21, 2025.  No appellate decision has yet been entered.

The TRO and preliminary‑injunction orders remain in effect.  The case has not yet produced a final judgment on the merits, but the court has affirmed its jurisdiction and the invalidity of the executive orders at the injunctive level.
results.46306:
On March 26, 2025, a coalition of nonprofit legal‑service organizations—Community Legal Services in East Palo Alto, Social Justice Collaborative, Amica Center for Immigrant Rights, Estrella del Paso, Florence Immigrant & Refugee Rights Project, Galveston‑Houston Immigrant Representation Project, Immigrant Defenders Law Center, National Immigrant Justice Center, Northwest Immigrant Rights Project, Rocky Mountain Immigrant Advocacy Network, and Vermont Asylum Assistance Project—filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California alleging that the United States Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), its Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR), and the Department of the Interior (DOI) had violated the William Wilberforce Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2008 (TVPRA) and the 2024 Unaccompanied Children Program Foundational Rule (45 C.F.R. § 410.1309(a)(4)), and that the defendants’ “Cancellation Order” on March 20/21, 2025 had abruptly terminated all federal funding for direct legal representation of unaccompanied immigrant children.  The plaintiffs claimed that this action infringed the statutory duty to “ensure…that all unaccompanied alien children…have counsel to represent them…and protect them from mistreatment, exploitation, and trafficking,” and that the APA (5 U.S.C. § 702) provided a basis to challenge the order.  They sought declaratory relief and a nationwide injunction to enjoin the defendants from withdrawing the funding, and to restore the status quo.

Judge Araceli Martinez‑Olguín granted the plaintiffs a temporary restraining order on April 1, 2025 and a preliminary injunction on April 29, 2025, ordering the defendants to continue providing the previously funded legal services.  The defendants appealed, arguing that the district court lacked jurisdiction because the funding decision was discretionary and that the APA did not authorize judicial review of a payment‑related action.  The Ninth Circuit, in a 2025 ruling, held that the district court had jurisdiction under the APA, that the injunction was appropriate, and denied the defendants’ motion for a stay pending appeal.  The court also denied a motion to recuse the judge, finding no conflict of interest, and denied the defendants’ subsequent motion to stay the preliminary injunction.  An emergency motion to stay the injunction was likewise denied.  No settlement was reached; the plaintiffs continue to seek enforcement of the injunction and the restoration of federal funding for legal representation of unaccompanied children.
results.46201:
On March 6 2025 the Attorneys General of California, Massachusetts, New Jersey, Colorado, Illinois, Maryland, New York, and Wisconsin—acting on behalf of their respective states—filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts (Case No. 1:25‑cv‑10548‑MJJ) against the United States Department of Education, its former Acting Secretary of Education Denise Carter (in her official capacity), and Secretary of Education Linda McMahon (in her official capacity).  The states allege that on February 7 2025 the Department abruptly terminated all previously‑awarded Teacher Quality Partnership (TQP) and Supporting Effective Educator Development (SEED) grants, which Congress authorized under 20 U.S.C. §§ 1022, 1022a, 6672.  The plaintiffs claim the terminations violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and seek declaratory relief and injunctive relief to vacate the terminations and prevent future cancellations.

The parties are not a class; the plaintiffs are eight sovereign states represented by their attorneys general.  The cause of action is the APA; the statutory basis is the federal grant statutes authorizing the TQP and SEED programs.  The remedy sought is declaratory and injunctive relief.

Jurisdiction was established on the basis of federal question jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. §§ 1331, 2201, 2202, and the APA (5 U.S.C. §§ 701‑706).  The district court, presided over by Judge Joun, D.J., entered a temporary restraining order (TRO) on March 10 2025, directing the Department to restore the pre‑termination status quo and to refrain from further terminating the grants.  The TRO was later extended to March 31 2025.  On April 8 2025 the Supreme Court, by a per curiam order, stayed the TRO pending the outcome of the pending appeal and the plaintiffs withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction.  The defendants subsequently filed a motion to dismiss or, alternatively, transfer the case to the Court of Federal Claims on May 12 2025, and the plaintiffs filed a First Amended Complaint on June 2 2025.  No further orders or judgments have been entered as of the latest docket entry.
results.46057:
On February 6, 2025, seven active‑duty U.S. military members—Commander Emily Shilling, Commander Blake Dremann, Lieutenant Commander Geirid Morgan, Sergeant First Class Cathrine Schmid, Sergeant First Class Jane Doe, Staff Sergeant Videl Leins, and Sergeant First Class Sierra Moran—together with a prospective service member, Matthew Medina, and the Gender Justice League, filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington.  The plaintiffs challenged the 2025 Military Ban (Executive Order 14183), which bars transgender persons from serving in the armed forces.  They allege that the ban violates the Fifth Amendment’s equal‑protection, due‑process, and First‑Amendment guarantees, and that the Department of Defense’s implementation of the ban is also subject to equitable estoppel.  The plaintiffs seek declaratory relief and a preliminary—and ultimately permanent—injunction to halt enforcement of the ban and the associated DoD guidance (“Hegseth policy”).

Judge Benjamin H. Settle granted the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction on March 27, 2025, ordering the government to suspend implementation of the ban and the Hegseth policy nationwide.  The Department of Defense appealed, asking the Ninth Circuit to issue a stay of the injunction pending review.  On April 18, 2025, the Ninth Circuit denied the stay.  The government then filed an application for a stay of the injunction with the U.S. Supreme Court on April 18, 2025.  The Supreme Court issued an order on May 6, 2025, granting an immediate stay of the preliminary injunction pending further review.  The case remains pending before the Supreme Court.
results.45984:
In the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, a group of transgender active‑duty and prospective service members—identified by names in the complaint but described here generically—filed a complaint on January 28 2025.  The plaintiffs alleged that President Donald J. Trump’s Executive Order 14183 (signed January 27 2025), which revokes the 2021 policy permitting transgender individuals to serve openly and declares that transgender status is incompatible with “high standards for troop readiness, lethality, cohesion, honesty, humility, uniformity, and integrity,” violates the Equal‑Protection component of the Fifth Amendment.  The order also requires the Secretary of Defense to update medical standards, prohibit pronoun use inconsistent with birth sex, and prohibits transgender service members from serving at all.

The plaintiffs sought declaratory, preliminary, and permanent injunctive relief, specifically a preliminary injunction to bar the Department of Defense from implementing the order and any related guidance.  Judge Ana C. Reyes granted that preliminary injunction on March 18 2025, ordering the DoD to maintain the status quo of military policy regarding transgender service and to preserve the plaintiffs’ enlistment and service status.  The court stayed the effect of that injunction until March 21 2025 to give the parties time to discuss a potential appeal.

On March 21 2025 the defendants filed a motion to dissolve the preliminary injunction.  Judge Reyes denied that motion on March 26 2025, holding that the injunction remained appropriate.  The defendants also sought a stay pending appeal, but the court denied that request on March 27 2025 and issued a memorandum opinion explaining its decision.  The case has been appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit (case 25‑5087).

No settlement has been reached, no monitoring arrangement has been established, and the case has not yet entered trial.  The factual basis of the claim is that the plaintiffs, who have served honorably in the armed forces for decades, were suddenly barred from continuing service and forced to resign or separate under the new executive order, which the plaintiffs argue amounts to unconstitutional discrimination.
results.45964:
The United States District Court for the Western District of Washington, under Judge John C. Coughenour, heard a complaint filed on January 21, 2025 (Case 2:25‑cv‑00127) by the State of Washington, the State of Arizona, the State of Illinois, and the State of Oregon—collectively the “Plaintiff States”—along with two individual plaintiffs, Cherly Norales Castillo and Alicia Chavarria Lopez.  The defendants are President Donald J. Trump (in his official capacity), the United States Department of Homeland Security, the Department of Social Security Administration, the Department of State, the Department of Health and Human Services, the Department of Justice, the Department of Agriculture, and the United States.  The plaintiffs allege that President Trump’s Executive Order No. 14160, “Protecting the Meaning and Value of American Citizenship,” issued January 20, 2025, unlawfully strips citizenship from children born in the United States to parents who are unlawfully present or temporarily present.  They claim the order violates the Fourteenth Amendment’s Citizenship Clause (Section 1) and the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. § 1401(a)), and seek declaratory relief and a preliminary injunction preventing enforcement and implementation of the order.

After the plaintiffs filed a motion for a temporary restraining order on the same day, the court granted it on January 23, 2025.  A preliminary injunction was issued on February 6, 2025, making the injunction nationwide.  The defendants filed a motion to stay the injunction pending appeal; the Ninth Circuit denied the stay on July 23, 2025.  The United States then filed an emergency application for partial stay, and on June 27, 2025, the Supreme Court granted a partial stay, limiting the injunction to the parties who had standing and removing its nationwide scope.  No settlement has been reached, and no monitoring order has been issued.  The case’s factual context is that the order would deprive tens of thousands of newborns and their families of citizenship‑related rights and federal benefits, and the plaintiff states argue that it would cause irreparable harm to their federal‑funded programs.  The case is ultimately an assertion of constitutional and statutory rights under the Fourteenth Amendment and the Immigration and Nationality Act, with the remedy sought being a declaratory judgment and injunctive relief to stop the order’s enforcement.
results.45965:
On January 21 2025, the nonprofit immigration‑rights organization CASA, Inc., the Asylum Seeker Advocacy Project, Inc., and eight pregnant plaintiffs—Maribel, Juana, Trinidad Garcia, Monica, Liza, Ashley, Andrea, and Niurka—filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland (Greenbelt Division).  The plaintiffs allege that President Donald J. Trump’s Executive Order 14‑160, signed on January 20 2025, unlawfully denies birthright citizenship to children born in the United States to parents who are either undocumented or present on temporary visas and whose fathers are neither U.S. citizens nor lawful permanent residents.  The complaint claims the order violates the Fourteenth Amendment’s Citizenship Clause and 8 U.S.C. § 1401, and it seeks declaratory relief and both preliminary and permanent injunctions prohibiting the enforcement of the order.

The court, Judge Deborah L. Boardman, granted a nationwide preliminary injunction on February 5 2025, barring all federal agencies and officials from applying the order to any child born in the United States after February 19 2025.  The defendants appealed the injunction and sought a stay.  The Fourth Circuit denied the stay, and the defendants then petitioned the Supreme Court.  On June 27 2025, the Supreme Court, in Trump v. CASA, Inc., 606 U.S. 2540 (2025), held that universal injunctions exceed the equitable authority granted by the Judiciary Act of 1789.  The Court granted the defendants’ partial stays, limiting the injunctions to the named plaintiffs and their identified associates, and directing that the orders not preclude agencies from drafting guidance on implementation.

Following the Supreme Court’s decision, the plaintiffs amended the complaint to bring a class action, seeking certification of a nationwide class of all children born in the United States after February 19 2025 to parents covered by the order.  A memorandum for class certification was filed; the court granted the motion, recognizing that the plaintiffs met the rule‑23 requirements for a class action.  The case remains pending on the merits, with the injunction continuing to apply to the plaintiffs’ names while the courts consider the constitutional and statutory claims.
results.VR-LA-0120:
The United States District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana entered the civil‑rights action on May 19, 2020. The plaintiffs were a group of voters and civic organizations—Telisa Clark, Lakeshia Barnett, Martha Christian Green, Crescent City Media Group, League of Women Voters Louisiana, and the Power Coalition for Equity and Justice with the Louisiana NAACP, Jane Chandler, Jennifer Harding, Edith Gee Jones, and Jasmine Pogue—who alleged that Louisiana’s election laws violated their constitutional rights. The defendants were state officials: Governor John Bel Edwards, Secretary of State Kyle Ardoin, Attorney General Jeff Landry, and parish registrars Charlene Meaux Menard and Rhonda R. Rogers. The plaintiffs’ counsel was private law practice, represented by the Southern Poverty Law Center, Fair Elections Center, and other attorneys.  

The complaint asserted violations of 42 U.S.C. §§ 1983 and 1988 (civil‑rights action), 52 U.S.C. § 10302, and Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act. The statutory and constitutional basis cited were the First Amendment’s right to vote, the Fourteenth Amendment’s due‑process and equal‑protection clauses, and the Voting Rights Act’s prohibition of disparate impact. Plaintiffs sought declaratory judgment and injunctive relief, specifically a preliminary injunction to enjoin enforcement of Louisiana’s “Excuse Requirement,” “Witness Requirement,” and “Cure Prohibition” in all 2020 elections.  

The case was consolidated with the earlier lawsuit “Power Coalition for Equity and Justice v. Edwards.” Judge Shelly D. Dick presided over the matter. After filing a motion for preliminary injunction on June 1, 2020, the plaintiffs’ motion to intervene was granted by the court on June 5, 2020. The state and the parish registrars filed motions to dismiss the complaint on June 8, 2020, and the attorney general filed a separate motion to dismiss on June 11, 2020. The court ultimately dismissed the complaint with prejudice on June 22, 2020, terminating the case. No trial, appeal, settlement, decree, or monitor was recorded. The factual basis for the claim was the plaintiffs’ risk of COVID‑19 exposure, the state’s emergency election plan that limited absentee voting, and the contested election provisions that plaintiffs argued imposed unconstitutional burdens on voters.
results.VR-SC-0078:
On April 22, 2020, a group of individual voters—Mary T. Thomas, Nea Richard, Jeremy Rutledge, Trena Walker, Dr. Brenda Williams, and the Family Unit, Inc.—filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina (Case No. 3:20‑cv‑01552‑JMC) against the South Carolina State Election Commission and the Governor, Marci Andino, John Wells, Clifford J. Edler, Scott Moseley, and Henry D. McMaster.  The plaintiffs, represented by the ACLU, NAACP, and other private counsel, alleged that the state’s absentee‑voting statutes—the “Excuse Requirement” (S.C. Code § 7‑15‑320) and the “Witness Requirement” (S.C. Code § 7‑15‑220)—unconstitutionally burden the right to vote under the First and Fourteenth Amendments, violate the Voting Rights Act (Section 2), and infringe the Americans with Disabilities Act.  They argued that, amid the COVID‑19 pandemic, these requirements force voters to choose between risking exposure to the virus or forgoing their vote, and that the law disproportionately harms African‑American voters.  The remedy sought was declaratory and injunctive relief, including an injunction that would enjoin enforcement of the challenged provisions for the 2020 election calendar.

Judge J. Michelle Childs oversaw the case.  On April 28, 2020, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction.  On May 8, 2020 the court granted a preliminary injunction that enjoined the Witness Requirement but did not enjoin the Excuse Requirement.  The injunction applied to the June 9, 2020 primary and the November 3, 2020 general election.  The court stayed the case pending further proceedings.  On August 10, 2020 the defendants moved for summary judgment, arguing that the plaintiffs failed to meet the burden of proof for a constitutional violation.  The court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants, finding no genuine dispute of material fact.  The plaintiffs’ amended complaint (July 13, 2020) added the South Carolina State Conference of the NAACP as an additional plaintiff; a related case, “Middleton v. Andino,” was filed concurrently to address the Witness Requirement.  

The South Carolina Republican Party, citing Rule 24, moved to intervene as a matter of right or, alternatively, permissively.  The court granted the party’s motion to intervene on May 8, 2020, allowing the party to participate in all subsequent proceedings.  No settlement has been reached, and the case remains pending.  No trial has yet been conducted, nor has the court issued a final judgment beyond the preliminary injunction and the defendants’ summary‑judgment ruling.
results.JC-MD-0017:
The action was filed on April 21, 2020 by a group of pre‑trial and post‑conviction detainees—Keith Seth, David Smith, Mario Burch, and John Doe 1–5—who represent a class of similarly situated persons at Prince George’s County Jail (PGCDOC).  Their counsel, a civil‑rights firm, sued the jail’s director, Mary Lou McDonough, alleging that the facility’s response to the COVID‑19 pandemic violated the detainees’ Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights through deficient conditions of confinement, unlawful over‑detention of COVID‑positive inmates, and failure to release medically vulnerable prisoners.  The plaintiffs also petitioned for writs of habeas corpus under 28 U.S.C. § 2241 and sought declaratory and injunctive relief.  Judge Paula Xinis presided over the case.

On May 21, 2020 the court entered a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction requiring the jail to provide basic hygiene supplies, adequate medical care, and to release COVID‑positive inmates who were no longer contagious.  In a letter order dated June 3, 2020 the court denied the defendant’s motion to stay the injunction pending appeal, finding that the TRO was not appealable and that McDonough had failed to meet the criteria for a stay.  The defendant complied with the court’s 14‑day reporting requirement and filed a motion to dismiss the plaintiffs’ amended complaint (filed July 7, 2020) on July 17, 2020, but the court denied that motion, leaving the amended claims and the injunction in place.

No trial, settlement, or appellate decision has yet been entered.  The case remains pending, with the plaintiffs continuing litigation to enforce the court’s injunctive orders and to challenge the jail’s ongoing COVID‑19 policies.
results.IM-FL-0029: On April 13 2020, civil immigration detainees held in the Krome Service Processing Center in Miami, the Broward Transitional Center in Pompano Beach, and the Glades County Detention Center in Moore Haven filed a petition for a writ of habeas corpus and a complaint in the Southern District of Florida, Miami Division. The petitioners, represented by private attorneys and legal‑aid groups, alleged that the Miami Field Office of ICE (Field Office Director Michael W. Meade) and the U.S. Attorney General William P. Barr had violated the detainees’ Fifth‑Amendment right to due process by maintaining detention conditions that, amid the COVID‑19 pandemic, failed to meet CDC guidelines and thereby exposed the detainees to serious health risk. The action is a class action covering all current and future detainees at the three facilities. The cause of action is grounded in the Fifth Amendment and the Accardi doctrine; no monetary damages are sought. The requested relief is declaratory and injunctive, including release of detainees and enforcement of health and safety measures. Judge Marcia G. Cooke presided over the case. The petitioners filed an emergency motion for a temporary restraining order and a motion for preliminary injunction on the filing date; a motion for class certification was filed on May 5 2020; a motion to compel compliance with the court’s orders was filed on May 20 2020. The court granted a temporary restraining order on April 30 2020 and a preliminary injunction on June 6 2020, ordering ICE to cease cohorting unconfirmed COVID‑19 cases, provide masks, cleaning supplies, and reduce the population to 75 % capacity. The court partially denied the class certification for the release claim but granted it for conditions‑of‑confinement claims on June 2 2020. On July 5 2020 the court granted the motion to compel compliance and appointed Special Master Matthew C. Stearns Weaver Miller to oversee compliance. No opinions, trials, or appeals are reported. A settlement agreement entered on June 28 2021 required ICE to continue complying with CDC guidelines, implement a vaccination plan, and maintain the conditions set forth in the final order; the settlement is court‑enforced. The special master continues to monitor compliance. The factual basis of the case centers on the COVID‑19 pandemic, CDC’s interim guidance on disease management in detention facilities, and the detainees’ inability to practice social distancing or obtain adequate hygiene supplies in the three facilities.
